Problem:
Analyze a mathematical system where the temperature distribution \\(T(x,t)\\) along a rod varies with time and position, governed by the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = \\alpha \\frac{\\partial^2 T}{\\partial x^2}\\), where \\(\\alpha\\) is the thermal diffusivity. Consider an intervention represented by a heat source term \\(S(x,t)\\) introduced at a position \\(x1\\) affecting the system.

If initially the temperature distribution is uniform, will the solution \\(T(x,t)\\) remain uniform over time without the intervention of additional heat sources?
Explanation: The uniform temperature distribution will evolve over time due to the diffusion term \\(\\frac{\\partial^2 T}{\\partial x^2}\\). In the absence of any source, the heat will naturally diffuse according to its gradient, leading to changes in temperature distribution.
